lines.text: Okay, now explain to me one more time how the rental car caught fire and exploded.
He called me a shithead and punched the car, it went rolling down a cliff.
Why did you punch the car?
Because the shithead threw the directions out the window and left my suitcase at the rental car agency.
Why did you throw the directions out the window?
Because they caught fire from my cigar ashes and were burning on my crotch!
The first time he's been hot down there for years.
I just wanted you to know what it felt like down there...
OK, boys, settle down. You two don't get along too well, do you?
Oh, that's not true. There was a period of 17 years that was wonderful. Then unfortunately we saw each other again.
And who did you say was getting married?
My daughter and his son.
[the Sheriff and all the deputies have to swallow a laugh]
Oscar, of all the fights that we've ever had, of all the arguments that we've ever had...
We can continue talking because he's going to be on this for a half-hour.

Of all the times that I've wanted to choke you by the throat, this is the worst! If you say "trifecta" one more time, I'm going to choke you until you are dead, and then that man can arrest me one more time for one more crime one more time in his office, AND HE'S GONNA HAVE A FOURFECTA! SO YOU SHUT THE FUCK UP, DO YOU HEAR ME?
I think you can get a fourfecta in Cuba, but it's a cigar.

[waking up in the car]
How long was I asleep?

[driving]
I don't know. I didn't know you wanted me to time it.
Where's my suitcase?
Your suitcase? In the trunk.
No.
No?
No.
Did you look good?

[holds his arms apart]
The trunk is this big. It takes about a second and a half to look in there. Your 1927 piece of cardboard is in there, but my suitcase isn't.
There are faster ways of delivery now. FedEx, UPS, fax...
Oh, you're gonna fax me my suitcase?
What do the directions say?
They're gone, I threw them out the window.

[laughing]
Oh, you threw them out the window... you threw them out the window? What the hell made you do a stupid thing like that?

Well, I had them on my lap so I could read them. I lit my cigar, the hot ashes fell on my crotch, the map caught fire. I had the choice of either finding the house, or burning up one of the most important parts of my body. Guess which I picked?
Don't get physical with me, Felix! I'm too old to hit, but I can spit you to death!

In that suitcase was my black formal afternoon suit that I bought to wear when I'm giving my daughter away in marriage. And in that suitcase was a $6,000 Tiffany silver tray that I bought as a wedding present. Oh, and in that suitcase was $10,000 in cash that I was going to give to my son-in-law on his wedding day. Now, in your suitcase, the police are going to find your broken, smashed, mutilated, and dissected body in the event that you don't go back and find my fucking suitcase!
Why don't we call Budget and ask them to deliver it?

Deliver, deliver where? You've already crisscrossed California more than the covered wagons did a hundred years ago! What the hell are we gonna tell them, follow the burnt pieces of directions on the freeway?
Why did you take his toupee?
We didn't! A truck whizzed by and blew it off, huh?
Yeah. I tried to get it back. A bird sat on it, I shooed him, and he flew away with the hairpiece.
You shot him? You had a gun?

No, no, not shot him, I shooed him. "Shoo, shoo!" Then a hunter shot him, the bird fell on top of the car, and the hairpiece fell on the windshield. I hope there's not gonna be a trial, because I'd hate to repeat that story in court.

Mom was married three times. You were married one time, and then never again for thirty years. Hers were too many, yours were not enough. So, tell me, what is wrong with it? What is it about marriage that frightens everybody so much?
I don't know, Brucey. It's like baseball, either you can play or you can't play. Your mother could play, I couldn't play. Trouble with your mother was she kept getting traded all the time.
Why, when you get around me, you start to behave like a goddamn, imbecilic, idiotic, totally moronic shithead?
Look, we have to have a plan, agreed?
Agreed.
Okay. What do you think the plan should be?
I don't care. I agreed. I did my part.
They've probably got poisonous spiders out here.
Get out of here, what are they gonna live on? You think they're waiting around for two schmucks like us to show up?
Was it San Marino?
Not San Marino, maybe San Quentino.
Not San Quentino, San Sorina.
No not San Sorina.
San Mateo. San Clemente. Roberto Clemente.
Sancho Pancho. Pancho Gonzales.
Ferrando Lamas, Ricardo Montalban.
Ricky Ricardo!
Los Pintos, Los Bresis, Los Picos. Sound familiar?
Yeah they're hotels in Aucopoco.
Ha ha! Look a car has to come from some direction. I'm gonna go stand on the other side of the road.
So we can catch all the heavy traffic at five o'clock at Los Picos.
Got a better idea, Los Idiot?
when you're gonna eat, when you're gonna pee, when you're gonna fart, when you're gonna cry, and when you're gonna sleep, because that's the last time I'm pulling off the freeway, ya hear?
Oh, and I suppose you never have to pee, huh?
I do it for a half hour in the morning, then I'm through for the day.
You got a lawyer?
Yeah, in Florida. He's 92. It takes him six hours to walk to the telephone. Case will be over.
[Felix and Oscar are sprayed by a crop dusting airplane]
What the hell was that?
They purposely did it. They hate New Yorkers.
Who's going to pick us up now? We look like a couple of Pillsbury Doughboys.
Well we'd better get out of the sun before we start to rise.
one for you to pee, one for you to let locked in the john, one to pay a kid $5 to get out, and then we'd have to stop again for you to eat. Do you understand what I'm talking about?
I'm having a dinner party Friday night, we're short one man.
How about Abe here, he's a short man.
You can run Oscar, but you can't hide! See ya.
Oh, that's such an original expression. I hate a woman who talks like Muhammed Ali.
[Felix dumps half a dozen different pills on the table]
How do you know which ones to take?
Doesn't make any difference. Whatever they fix, I got.
You know, Oscar, if I didn't know better, I'd say a nice old grandfather like you was trying to hit on a couple of ladies.
I'm not as old as I look. I had this plastic surgery done recently, and the quack doctor botched it up.
Your friend doesn't say much, does he?
He's the doctor who botched it up.
The wick is almost out, Felix. All I want is for the candle to glow one last time rather than curse the darkness.
It's not going out, Oscar, not yours and not mine. But I still have hope that somewhere out there we'll find the right lamplighter.
You know, we just used so many metaphors I forgot what the hell we were talking about.
Better pull off the freeway, Oscar, I have to eat. I have a low sugar condition, I have to eat every four hours.
Why the hell didn't you eat when we were back at El Pollo Loco?
Because it wasn't time to eat yet, it was time to pee. Sheesh!
Hello there. What do you want?
Five dollars.
Why should I give you five dollars?
Your friend said you would for telling you that he's locked in the bathroom.
Tell me when it hurts.
It hurts!
I got an idea, don't tell me when it hurts cause it's gonna hurt anyway. Okay here we go, one, two three.

[Slides into the car]
Aaaaaahh! Ooh! Oh! Oh!
I liked 'it hurts' better.
What freeway are we supposed to be on?
The 405.
I think that sign back there said 101.
If you didn't have the brains to pee back at the airport, how could you possibly read that sign?
Reading and peeing are two different things!
At your age you're lucky you can do either one.
Don't you take them with water?
The local water?
[Very loudly]
Don't you know how many pesticides there are in the local water?
Lower your voice, will you? People in here don't know they're gonna be dead in a week.
[In the middle of the desert]
Look instead of complaining, why don't you look around for a telephone.
What the hell makes you think there'd be a telephone anywhere out here? This is probably where they test those nuclear bombs.
Well they would have to call somebody to find out if they went off wouldn't they?
You thinking about moving out here, Pop?
To where? Santa Yosinta-Malienta-Poliguenta? I'm not gonna learn another language just to find my way home at night.
[in the desert]
I think I figured out where we are.
Where?
In a Clint Eastwood movie.
What's the matter, don't you look at a good ass anymore?
I'm not allowed to look at Pastrami, why should I look at an ass?
He's like my third husband, he should rest in peace.
How do you know he's dead? Maybe he's just bluffing.
Felix, I haven't seen you in what, 8, 9 years?
Seventeen! Seventeen years, Oscar, you couldn't remember that we haven't seen each other for seventeen years?

To tell you the truth I didn't dwell on it. Alright, seventeen years, so your hair got whiter, your ears got bigger, your nose got longer, but you still retain that unique, elusive pain in the ass quality that drives me berserk.
Oh really?
We've always had bad chemistry, Felix. We mix like oil and frozen yogurt.

[clearing his sinuses]
Snah!
Didn't you fix that yet?
Look at these shorts. I feel like I could be a cocktail waitress at a crap game.
Yeah, if you wiggle your fanny right you can make double sixes.
Oscar, what are two wide-awake girls going to do with one hunky, funny guy?
Why don't we all write a suggestion on a piece of paper?
Blanche, would you stop pointing your finger at me and yelling. You got two other husbands here to do that with.
I know I haven't been there a lot for you, Brucey, but this is the best advice I'll ever give you, not getting married today is the right thing for you to do.
Maybe it's right for you, it's wrong for me! You tell everybody I'm getting dressed.
Thank God you said that. I wasn't sure how long I could keep on talking like an asshole.
Nothing has changed, Felix. I'm still a pig, you're still a human vacuum cleaner.
[last lines]
This is the biggest, goddamnest deja vu anybody has ever had. Can we please play cards here, for crying out loud?
We'd better call Budget and have them fax us another car.
If we go down, you go down with us!
Who are you, Dirty Harry?
Maybe we can stop somewhere and get a pair of crutches.
Yeah I'll keep my eye open for crutch stores, I'm sure there's a lot of them on the freeway.

[in a wheelchair, Oscar is pushing]
We haven't even said hello yet and already I've got a sprained ankle. Let me know when we come to a bump.
[They roll over a bump]
Ow!
That's one.
Okay what do you wanna talk to me about?
Wait until the seat belt light is off.
You can't talk with your seat belt on? Is that some new federal law?
He just missed someone in crowd!
What crowd? We could all go home in one car.
I hope you won't be offended by my saying I hope to God I never see either of you two again.
You just have to help me figure out a reason why I should get up and go sit next to her.
How about... ummm... .I don't know. How about, your seat is broken?
No, 'cos I'm a bad liar, she'll know I'm lying.
How about if I break your seat?
So the man is dead, and you have his wallet, riding in an antique car that's worth over $150,000. How do you think this looks?
To you it looks terrible. My mother, she wouldn't be all that upset.
Never count me out until the fat lady divorces me!
I hate mess and I hate disorder. I went to a hypnotist to try and cure me.
Didn't work, huh?
Na, he was late. I straightened up his office and left.
[In the desert]
I think I just seen Omar Sharif on a camel.
We have so much in common, did you know the first four letters of our names are the same?
Now that you mention it, yeah, we do.
You know, neither of you wear glasses either?
I'm not going back with you, Oscar, I'm moving in with Lise for a few days.
Lise?
Felise, she likes it when I call her that.
What does she call you, Lix?
Anyway, I'm moving to San Fran with her.
Lise? Lix? San Fran? What the hell is going on?
If anyone gets tough, just show them your underwear.
[the Sheriff has sent Oscar and Felix away for the third and final time]
Andy, if those guys commit a triple-murder or rob a bank, just let them go.

[after his son Brucey tells him he's marrying Felix Ungar's daughter]
She's WHOSE daughter?
[Felix and Oscar are arrested and having to sit before the sheriff a second time around]
So the man is dead, and you have his wallet, riding in an antique car that's worth over $150,000. How do you think this looks?
To you it looks terrible. My mother, she wouldn't be all that upset.
Look, we didn't murder him and we didn't rob him. Now, you believed us before, so why don't you believe us now?
Because I didn't expect the two of you to keep bouncing back in here like a beachball.

[to Felix and Oscar about to leave from having been released on their second arrest]
If I see you two back in here under arrest again, then I seriously will charge you with disturbing the law!
Don't you mean "disturbing the peace"?
No, it's only the law you're disturbing.
[Felix and Oscar have just been arrested and are having to face the sheriff for a third time, who is horrified about the circumstance]
So, do you even want to talk about it?
No.
Ever?
What's the point? It seems like no matter what I say, you two still end up in here.

[looking over at the sheriff's deputy]
Would it be possible to get the results of a race at Santa Anita? I got a trifecta going.
A what?
A trifecta. It is where you pick the three winning horses in order from start to finish.
You are unbelievable. We have a wedding we cannot get to, and all he's got in his mind is a trifecta.
I'll tell you who won.
You know?
Yes! I won. Don't you see? You're my trifecta. The same two men have been arrested three different times and all three times by my men. Do you know what the odds are of that happening?
I would say roughly 12 million to one.
And what would it be if it were to happen in a little town called Santa Menandez, California?
It would be in the trillions. No bookie could handle it.
